marklogic.body: (Supposedly) We invaded Afghanistan because their government, the Taliban, was harboring Al Qaeda, who attacked us on 9/11, and refused to turn them over to us. So vengeance would be one reason. A secondary reason is that the Taliban was an oppressive (an understatement) regime, that denied freedoms to the citizens of Afghanistan. Soooooo, we invaded, and made it so the Taliban no longer had control of the country. But we never really captured or killed all the Taliban, or Al Qaeda because they took to hiding in the very mountainous countryside, or ran to Pakistan. Plus, the ten-years-long battle with insurgents distracted us from completing the mission as well as distracted us from nation-building (--training an army, police, providing safety for the new government and re-building infrastructure). According to some, conditions in the country are better. According to others, they are worse. It wasn't a perfect plan, or execution. Nor will it come to a perfect conclusion (we will look incompetent and have blood on our hands). BUT, I believe that vengeance for 9/11 and dismantling the oppressive fundamentalist Islamic regime were good reasons for invading Afghanistan. I believe that we should chase our enemies anywhere they may be hiding. I believe we should use military means to Ensure our fellow citizens of this world are not oppressed and/or denied basic human rights, which we and hundreds of other nations have agreed are necessary. I believe that leaving the country in a state of chaos would be morally irresponsible. And if we are as moral as we claim to be, and I say we are, then we shouldn't do that. I take solace in the fact that I believe we have learned our lesson. Sadly, incidents like Burning holy books and mentally ill soldiers slipping through the filters are just the intrinsic natures of our system.
